pull.title: tests: Add noverify_tests which is like tests but without VERIFY
pull.body:
mentioned in https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/issues/1037#issuecomment-1371870423

Let's see how this affects CI time

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body:
> Let's see how this affects CI time

Less than I expected:

master: https://cirrus-ci.com/build/6730654054875136
this PR: https://cirrus-ci.com/build/4723750860488704


What do you think? Is this useful? If yes, should we just keep it as is or reduce the test iterations?
I think we can leave it as-is. I think only the duration of the longest-running CI job really matters, and that seems barely affected.

> I think we can leave it as-is. I think only the duration of the longest-running CI job really matters, and that seems barely affected.

Indeed. Ready for review then.
Instead of disabling `-DVERIFY` for `tests` if coverage is enabled, maybe just disable `tests` (and leave `noverify_tests`)?

events.message: tests: Add noverify_tests which is like tests but without VERIFY

events.body:
> Instead of disabling `-DVERIFY` for `tests` if coverage is enabled, maybe just disable `tests` (and leave `noverify_tests`)?

done
